Afterword


In October, 1972, camping in Acadia National Park on the Maine coast, I read a nature book.

properties.context: As one-inch elvers they wriggled and heaved their way from the salt sea up the coastal rivers of America and Europe, upstream always into “the quiet upper reaches of rivers and brooks, in lakes and ponds—sometimes as high as 8,000 feet above sea level.”

properties.name: Europe
properties.context: Twenty thousand head of domestic livestock died in Europe from a host of black flies that swarmed from the banks of the Danube in 1923.

properties.name: Europe
properties.context: When Western surgeons discovered how to perform safe cataract operations, they ranged across Europe and America operating on dozens of men and women of all ages who had been blinded by cataracts since birth.

properties.name: Europe
properties.context: Starlings came to this country on a passenger liner from Europe.

properties.name: Europe
properties.context: Not too long ago, according to Edwin Way Teale, the people of Europe believed that geese and swans wintered there, on the moon’s pale seas.

properties.name: the North Atlantic
properties.context: Down streams to rivers, down rivers to the sea, south in the North Atlantic where they meet and pass billions of northbound elvers, they are returning to the Sargasso Sea, where, in floating sargassum weed in the deepest waters of the Atlantic, they will mate, release their eggs, and die.

properties.name: East Africa
properties.context: I infer that we have got poisonous snakes as East Africa has zebras or the tropics have orchids—they are our specialty, our stock-in-trade.

properties.name: Antarctic
properties.context: Lice live in the hollow quills of birds’ feathers, in warthog bristles, in Antarctic seals’ flippers and pelican pouches.

properties.name: Antarctic
properties.context:
Finally, Paul Siple, the Antarctic explorer and scientist, writes of the Antarctic crab-eater seal, which lives in the pack ice off the continent: “One seldom finds a sleek silvery adult crab-eater that does not bear ugly scars—or two-foot long parallel slashes—on each side of its body, received when it managed somehow to wriggle out of the jaws of a killer whale that had seized it.”
I think of those crab-eater seals, and the jaws of the killer whales lined with teeth that are, according to Siple, “as large as bananas.”

properties.name: Antarctic
properties.context:

I think of those crab-eater seals, and the jaws of the killer whales lined with teeth that are, according to Siple, “as large as bananas.”

properties.name: Antarctic
properties.context: Still, it is to the picture of the “sleek silvery” crab-eater seals that I return, seals drawn up by scientists from the Antarctic ice pack, seals bearing again and again the long gash marks of unthinkable teeth.

properties.name: Adams

properties.name: Adams

properties.name: Hudson’s Bay

properties.name: Hudson’s Bay
properties.context: It looked as though the leaves of the autumn forest had taken flight, and were pouring down the valley like a waterfall, like a tidal wave, all the leaves of hardwoods from here to Hudson’s Bay.

properties.name: Hudson’s Bay
properties.context: The books I read are like the stone men built by the Eskimos of the great desolate tundras west of Hudson’s Bay.

properties.name: Arctic Ocean
properties.context: Up on the Arctic Ocean coasts, Eskimos dry the late summer’s fish on drying racks, to use throughout the winter as feed for dogs.

properties.name: northing

properties.context: Shall I go northing?

properties.name: North
properties.context: I long for the North where unimpeded winds would hone me to such a pure slip of bone.

properties.name: North
properties.context: The North washes down the mountains like a waterfall, like a tidal wave, and pours across the valley; it comes to me.

properties.name: North
properties.context: In the South, the periodical cicada has a breeding cycle of thirteen years, instead of seventeen years as in the North.

properties.name: North

properties.name: Dead Man Mountain
properties.context: The sun heaves to the south by day, and at night wild Orion emerges looming like the Specter of the Brocken over Dead Man Mountain.

properties.name: Dead Man Mountain
properties.context: The first time I discovered this mystery I looked from cloud to no-cloud in bewilderment, checking my bearings over and over, thinking maybe the ark of the covenant was just passing by south of Dead Man Mountain.

properties.name: Dead Man Mountain
properties.context: Behind me, Tinker Mountain, and to my left, Dead Man Mountain, are eroding one thousandth of an inch a year.

properties.name: Gulf

properties.name: Polaris

properties.name: Lake Superior
properties.context: They fly over Lake Superior without resting; in fact, observers there have discovered a curious thing.

properties.name: Lake Superior
properties.context: In another book I read that geologists think that Lake Superior marks the site of the highest mountain that ever existed on this continent.

properties.name: Brushy
properties.context: A few weeks before the monarch migration I visited Carvin’s Cove, a reservoir in a gap between Tinker and Brushy mountains, and there beside the forest path I saw, it occurs to me now, Abba Moses, in the form of an acorn.

properties.name: Brushy
properties.context: On an evening in late May, a moist wind from Carvin’s Cove shoots down the gap between Tinker and Brushy mountains, tears along Carvin’s Creek valley, and buffets my face as I stand by the duck pond.

properties.name: Canada
properties.context: Last year I saw three migrating Canada geese flying low over the frozen duck pond where I stood.

properties.name: Canada
properties.context: In interior Alaska and northern Canada, breakup is the big event.

properties.name: Canada
properties.context: Jacob set out for Canaan with his wives and twelve sons, the fathers of the twelve tribes of Israel, and with these cattle that are Israel’s heritage, into Egypt and out of Egypt, just as the intricate speckled and spotted world is ours.

properties.name: West Virginia
properties.context: To West Virginia, where it snubbed on a high ridge, snared by trees, and sifted in shards over the side?

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: Somewhere, everywhere, there is a gap, like the shuddering chasm of Shadow Creek which gapes open at my feet, like a sudden split in the window or hull of a high-altitude jet, into which things slip, or are blown, out of sight, vanished in a rush, blasted, gone, and can no more be found.

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: Shadow Creek is the blue subterranean stream that chills Carvin’s Creek and Tinker Creek; it cuts like ice under the ribs of the mountains, Tinker and Dead Man.

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: Shadow Creek storms through limestone vaults under forests, or surfaces anywhere, damp, on the underside of a leaf.

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: Shadow Creek: on my least walk to the mailbox I may find myself knee-deep in its sucking, frigid pools.

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: But that night Tinker Creek had vanished, usurped, and Shadow Creek blocked its banks.

properties.name: Shadow Creek
properties.context: The chloroplasts do stream in the leaf as if propelled by a mighty, invisible breath; but on the other hand, a certain sorrow arises, welling up in Shadow Creek, and from those lonely banks it appears that all our intricate fringes, however beautiful, are really the striations of a universal and undeserved flaying.

properties.name: Kenya
properties.context: Isak Dinesen in Kenya, her heart utterly broken by loss, stepped out of the house at sunrise, seeking a sign.

Seeing


When I was six or seven years old, growing up in Pittsburgh, I used to take a precious penny of my own and hide it for someone else to find.

properties.name: Pittsburgh
properties.context: The school was in Shadyside, a busy residential part of Pittsburgh.

properties.name: Pittsburgh
properties.context: I remember how sycamores grew—and presumably still grow—in the city, in Pittsburgh, even along the busiest streets.

properties.name: Pittsburgh
properties.context: It is hard to understand how the same tree could thrive both choking along Pittsburgh’s Penn Avenue and slogging knee-deep in Tinker Creek.

properties.name: Pittsburgh
properties.context: It appears complete, in full color, wordless, though already receding: the tennis courts on Fifth Avenue in Pittsburgh, an equestrian statue in a Washington park, a basement dress shop in New York City—scenes that I thought meant nothing to me.

properties.name: Pittsburgh
properties.context: The tomcat that used to wake me is dead; he was long since grist for an earthworm’s casting, and is now the clear sap of a Pittsburgh sycamore, or the honeydew of aphids sucked from that sycamore’s high twigs and sprayed in sticky drops on a stranger’s car.

properties.name: China

properties.name: Peru

properties.context: If you ever drive through Virginia on the new interstate highway between Christiansburg and Salem, and you feel a slight dip in the paving under your wheels, then loose thy shoe from off thy foot, for the place whereon thou drivest is Jean White’s horse.

properties.name: Salem
properties.context: If you ever drive through Virginia on the new interstate highway between Christiansburg and Salem, and you feel a slight dip in the paving under your wheels, then loose thy shoe from off thy foot, for the place whereon thou drivest is Jean White’s horse.

properties.name: Roanoke
properties.context: It was very simple; I went to a store in Roanoke called “Wet Pets”; I handed the man a quarter, and he handed me a knotted plastic bag bouncing with water in which a green plant floated and the goldfish swam.

properties.name: Breughel
properties.context: We go down landscape after mobile, sculpture after collage, down to molecular structures like a mob dance in Breughel, down to atoms airy and balanced as a canvas by Klee, down to atomic particles, the heart of the matter, as spirited and wild as any El Greco saints.

properties.name: earth
properties.context: But here on earth texture interests us supremely.

properties.name: Alps
properties.context: In the eighteenth century, when educated European tourists visited the Alps, they deliberately blindfolded their eyes to shield themselves from the evidence of the earth’s horrid irregularity.

properties.name: Alps
properties.context: But here we live and move; we wander up and down the banks of the creek, we ride a railway through the Alps, and the landscape shifts and changes.

properties.name: Saturn
properties.context: Were the earth as smooth as a ball bearing, it might be beautiful seen from another planet, as the rings of Saturn are.

properties.name: the Severn Bore
properties.context: They should train their cameras instead on the melting of pack ice, the green filling of ponds, the tidal swing of the Severn Bore.

properties.name: Alpha Centauri
properties.context: People say that a good seat in the backyard affords as accurate and inspiring a vantage point on the planet earth as any observation tower on Alpha Centauri.

properties.name: Mount Katahdin
properties.context: Thoreau climbs Mount Katahdin and gives vent to an almost outraged sense of the reality of the things of this world: “I fear bodies, I tremble to meet them.

properties.name: Egypt
properties.context: Jacob set out for Canaan with his wives and twelve sons, the fathers of the twelve tribes of Israel, and with these cattle that are Israel’s heritage, into Egypt and out of Egypt, just as the intricate speckled and spotted world is ours.

properties.name: Egypt
properties.context: Jacob set out for Canaan with his wives and twelve sons, the fathers of the twelve tribes of Israel, and with these cattle that are Israel’s heritage, into Egypt and out of Egypt, just as the intricate speckled and spotted world is ours.

properties.name: Baltimore
properties.context: Baltimore orioles are here; brown thrashers seem to be nesting down by Tinker Creek across the road.

properties.name: Tara
properties.context: The long-haired girls strayed into giggling clumps at the corner of the road; the garbage trucks sped away gloriously, as if they had been the Tarleton twins on thoroughbreds cantering away from the gates of Tara.

properties.name: Richmond
properties.context: On the same day that I was standing on bridges here over Tinker Creek, a friend, Lee Zacharias, was standing on a bridge in Richmond over the James River.

properties.name: Richmond
properties.context: Lee knew, all of Richmond knew: it was coming.

properties.name: the James River
properties.context: On the same day that I was standing on bridges here over Tinker Creek, a friend, Lee Zacharias, was standing on a bridge in Richmond over the James River.

properties.name: the James River
properties.context: The James River was up a mere nine feet, which didn’t look too unusual.

properties.name: James
properties.context: There the James ultimately rose thirty-two feet.

properties.name: Maryland
properties.context: Later Agnes would move on up into Maryland, Pennsylvania, and New York, killing people and doing hundreds of millions of dollars worth of damage.

properties.name: Wilkes-Barre
properties.context: I talked to one of the helicopter pilots who had helped airlift ancient corpses from a flooded cemetery in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania.

properties.name: Vietnam
properties.context: The one I talked to, in a little sandwich shop at the Peaks of Otter on the Blue Ridge Parkway, preferred Vietnam.
